snippet: Eight deaths in a Staten Island enclave during Hurricane Sandy have raised questions about why the victims were in their homes when the storm hit and whether the city bore some responsibility for their failure to evacuate.
abstract: Eight deaths in Staten Island enclave of Midland Beach during Hurricane Sandy have raised questions about why victims were in their homes when storm hit and whether city bears some responsibility for their failure to evacuate; relatives, friends and officials have replayed events of night, pondering whether they should have done something different and whether city needs to improve its evacuation procedures.

byline.original: By KIRK SEMPLE and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

lead_paragraph: Eight deaths in a Staten Island enclave during Hurricane Sandy have raised questions about why the victims were in their homes when the storm hit and whether the city bore some responsibility for their failure to evacuate.

headline.seo: How a Staten Island Community Became a Deathtrap
headline.main: How a Beach Community Became a Deathtrap
headline.print_headline: How a Beach Community Became a Deathtrap
